Author: ryanb
Content: I'm honestly surprised by all the fuss over xobni. I have it running on my Outlook at work, where I get a ton of e-mails per day, and I frankly haven't found it to be very useful as of yet. Maybe I haven't fooled with it enough.

Author: kirubakaran
Content:
"If they price their product for $100 a license, then they'd only have to sell 200,000 licenses a year to reach $20 million a year."

Since the price of MS Office Home Edition is $150, imho they will have a tough time justifying a price higher than $29.99 (with the current feature set of Xobni at least). Don't get me wrong - I like Xobni... I am just saying this from a practical sales standpoint.

Considering this and considering they have to pay income tax instead of capital gains tax, they may have to sell at least a million copies to make $20 million.

Of course they can make it into a product with a ton more features making it worth $100 a piece in the eyes of Joe CubeDweller.

Author: justin
Title: Justin.tv is hiring the smartest hackers from News.YC
Content:
We got abstractbill. Who is next?

Justin.tv is the biggest Flash live video site online. We serve hundreds of thousands of video streams a day, and have supported up to 30k live concurrent viewers. Our site is growing every week, and we just signed a contract for a 2gbps commit in our colo. Our unique visitors are up 900% since January, and we just broke the Alexa Top 500 yesterday.

There are a lot of pieces that fit together to make Justin.tv work: our video cluster, IRC server, our web app, and our monitoring and search services, to name a few. Both our video and chat servers are written in the Twisted framework, and we're looking for talented engineers who want to improve these things and build more.

Responsibilities

    * Contribute to product design and implementation discussions
    * Implement projects from the idea phase to production
    * Test and iterate code before and after production release
Qualifications

    * We like dynamic languages. You should too. A lot of the things we build are in Twisted or Rails.
    * Experience building web applications.
    * A strong desire to work on website with passionate users and ideas for how to improve it.
    * Experience hacking video streams, python, Twisted or rails all a plus.
While we're growing rapidly, Justin.tv is still a small, technology focused company, built by hackers for hackers. Six of our eight person team are engineers or designers. We believe in rapid development, and push out new code releases every week. We're based in a beautiful office (see pics) in the SOMA district of SF, one block from the caltrain station. If you want a fun job hacking on code that will touch a lot of people, JTV is for you.

Note: You must be physically present in SF to work for JTV. Completing the technical problem at http://jtvproblems.weebly.com (for non-Flash devs) will go a long way with us. Cheers!

Author: jdavid
Content: this does not look like an IP buy for MS, it looks like a human capitol buy.  It's one thing to have a product, a business and be allowed the freedom to innovate.  Its another thing to be brought in and fix someone-else's problem.  Its my guess that MS wanted Xobni to re-vitalize outlook rather than advance their product.

Author: dkozzles
Title: Seed Funded Company Looking for Web Developer
Content:
Looking for a Fun Summer Job?

Want your work actually to make a direct and tangible difference? Looking for a fun place where you will be taken seriously and will personally shape the direction of a budding company?

StudyBuddy is an online academic networking startup aimed at facilitating student-to-student academic communication and interaction on college campuses. StudyBuddy, started by Harvard undergraduates, was recently named a finalist in Harvard's new $80,000 "Innovation Challenge," and was one of 12 teams chosen from more than 200 to participate in a summer business incubator program this summer. StudyBuddy is in its early stages, and is looking for another team member to join us in developing on our revolutionary academic communication framework.

Summer interns will join the StudyBuddy team, receiving competitive compensation and the potential to receive equity in the company, becoming a central figure as we grow beyond the summer. Interns should have PHP, HTML and CSS experience. Knowledge of servers/web hosting, MySQL, and graphic design are a plus. Above all, we're looking for someone who's excited to join a high potential company that will affect the lives of students across the country.

Interested in learning more?

Contact: Shankar Ramaswamy (Ramaswam@fas.harvard.edu)

Author: albertcardona
Content:
I have just recently created a command line utility for making clojure scripts/plugins for ImageJ, from within ImageJ. Release details very soon at http://pacific.mpi-cbg.de/wiki

Clojure is an excellent language for extending any java application and using java libraries.

Author: emmett
Content: 16 "must have died"...just goes to show that startups don't really die, they just fade away. The only YC startup I know of that officially ended at a specific time is Kiko; are there others?

Author: DaniFong
Content: 'When it comes to business and relationships, I don't buy this idea of diversification. It neglects comparative advantage. The best way to lower risk is to specialize: Put the things that you love into one portfolio.'

Author: rms
Content:
My newish blog got a PR4 yesterday, this is with 10 PR5/6 blog post links, a .edu link, a blogroll or two, and a whole lot of reddit links.

And... be careful. Generally this audience doesn't care about SEO topics, so continually submitting your SEO blog is an easy way to get banned.

Author: dangoldin
Content:
The thing that struck me was the point about Moore's Law not being applicable to cars - which seems to go against his point of not believing in limits.

If we all expected cars to double their efficiency every 2 years maybe people would be working on that just like they are working hard to double the number of transistors every 2 years.
